ES.1 Introduction 



The Southern California Gas Company (SoCalGas) Wheeler Ridge Compressor Station (Station) is at 9530 California Highway 166, Mettler, Kern County, California. To reduce nitrogen oxide emissions, the Station uses anhydrous ammonia, which is classified as an acutely hazardous material in the state of California. The Station stores anhydrous ammonia in a 12,000-gallon aboveground storage tank. SoCalGas has a strong safety culture and takes their safety obligations very seriously, ensuring that operators involved in the use of anhydrous ammonia are trained and knowledgeable in the chemical hazards associated with their jobs. 

The following Risk Management Plan (RMP) describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, some of the steps taken to ensure a safely operating Station, and how chemical emergencies are handled. This RMP complies with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program under California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 and the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP regulations in the Code of Federal Regulations Title 40, Part 68. 



ES.2 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 



The SoCalGas accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, and tested management system practices. Applicable procedures of the State of California are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

SoCalGas management recognizes the responsibility to make the environment, community, and employee safety a primary part of daily concerns. SoCalGas is committed to being a responsible member in the community by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner. The prevention of accidents and protection of its employees, property, and the general public are ess

ential to the efficient and successful completion of every project undertaken by the Station. SoCalGas requires active injury and illness prevention as an important element of daily operation. 

Every employee is entitled to a safe and healthy place in which to work under SoCalGas policy. SoCalGas incorporates the concepts of environmental responsibility and productivity with safety resulting in efficiency and productivity. As part of the SoCalGas obligation to protect the integrity of human, environmental, physical, and financial resources, and to conserve and efficiently use those resources, SoCalGas will: 

?    Comply fully with laws regulating environmental protection and employee health and safety. 

?    Furnish workplaces free of recognized hazards likely to cause injury to employees, the public, or the environment. 

?    Train employees in safe and environmentally conscious practices and require compliance with environmental, health, and safety regulations, policies, and procedures. 

?    Provide a professional staff to maintain and support environmental, health, and safety programs. 



ES.3 General Station and Regulated Substances Information 



The Station uses anhydrous ammonia as the reagent in the Selective Catalytic Reduction systems for control of nitrogen oxides emissions from the compressor turbines. Anhydrous ammonia is a covered chemical under state and federal RMP regulations.  

Anhydrous ammonia is stored in a 12,000-gallon capacity storage tank. Mechanical controls limit the capacity of the tank to 80 percent of maximum capacity. The maximum inventory of anhydrous ammonia is approximately 54,300 pounds (approximately 10,500 gallons). This quantity exceeds the CalARP threshold of 500 pounds of anhydrous ammonia and the federal EPA RMP threshold and Process Safety Management (PSM) threshold of 10,000 pounds of ammonia. The anhydrous ammonia process is subject to Program Level 3. 



ES.4 Summary of the 5-Year Accident History 



The Station has

had no accidents involving anhydrous ammonia that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. SoCalGas maintains a comprehensive incident investigation and emergency response program in the event of an occurrence. Ongoing emergency response training provides the personnel and resources familiarity with procedures and available resources. 



ES.5 Summary of the Emergency Response Program 



SoCalGas has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the Station, which establishes emergency response procedures designed to protect personnel, to limit damage to the environment, and to ensure that proper notifications are made to the appropriate government agencies. The EAP details the response procedures, protective measures, levels of training, regulatory notification requirements, and post-incident follow-up procedures. The EAP also identifies emergency assembly areas, evacuation routes, and related procedures to be undertaken during emergency scenarios.  



In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release, the highest-ranking operations person on site will assess whether the release is controllable or uncontrollable. If the release is controllable, trained personnel will perform the tasks necessary to accomplish containment and mitigation of the release. If the release is uncontrollable, the highest-ranking person on site will notify the Kern County Fire Department. The Kern County Fire Department will handle spill/release response and mitigation.  



The EAP is coordinated (reviewed) by the Kern County Fire Department, which is a member of the Local Emergency Planning Committee. The Station works closely with the Kern County Fire Department to coordinate response actions and review the anhydrous ammonia system. In addition, employees are trained on the EAP when initially hired, and all employees receive annual refresher training

on emergency response. Details of the EAP are provided in Section 4. 



ES.6 Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps  



The prevention program for the anhydrous ammonia process is discussed in a separate document, Prevention Program, Wheeler Ridge Compressor Station, Program 3 Risk Management Plan for Anhydrous Ammonia, and is briefly summarized below.  



Employee Participation 

Participation of Wheeler Ridge Compressor Station staff the RMP/PSM and other safety programs is critical to successful implementation. The Station has developed a written employee participation plan to describe how employees are involved in developing the RMP/PSM program and how they will continue to be involved in future modifications to the program. 





Process and Chemical Safety Information 

The Station compiles and maintains up-to-date safety information related to the regulated substances, processes, and equipment at the Station. This information is used to identify and understand the hazards in operating the anhydrous ammonia process. The safety information includes safety data sheets, a process description, maximum intended inventory, safe operating limits, equipment specifications, and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the system.  



Process Hazard Analysis 

The Station conducts hazard reviews or process hazard analyses (PHA) to improve safety and reduce the consequences of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. The hazard review identifies the process hazards, opportunities for equipment malfunctions or human errors, safeguards used to control hazards, and steps used to detect or monitor releases. The hazard review is revalidated or updated at least once every 5 years. Revalidation dates are based on the original PHA completion date. 



Operating Procedures 

The Station maintains up-to-date, accurate, and written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for the anhydrous am

monia process. Operating procedures are required for applicable stages of system operation, including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown operations, normal shutdown, startup following normal and emergency shutdown, consequences of deviations, steps required to correct or avoid deviations, and equipment inspections.  



Review and revalidation of procedures will be conducted as often as necessary to ensure they are current.  Procedures will be certified annually to validate that the content is current and accurately reflect current process safety information and/or industry standards. 



Training 

The Station has developed an overall written plan of action to implement and maintain training requirements. The plan specifically includes participation of employees involved in the operation and maintenance of the ammonia processes in the hazard review. Employees must be trained on anhydrous ammonia operating or maintenance procedures, safety and health hazards, and safe work practices before they can operate or maintain the covered process. The Station has developed a written employee training program and associated training materials and training records. The training program includes initial training, refresher training, and documentation of the training. Refresher training for the ammonia process is provided at least every 3 years.  





Contractors 

The SoCalGas has a Contractor Safety Program that ensure that only contractors with good safety programs are selected to perform work on and around the ammonia process and that the contractors are properly informed of the hazards, access limitations to these process areas, and emergency action procedures, and prepared to safely complete the work. SoCalGas holds contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the process areas, controls access to the process areas, and evaluates the contractor's performance. 



Pre-Startup Safety Review  

SoCalGas has proce

dures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the ammonia system that require a Management of Change procedure implementation. These procedures ensure that no new/significantly modified process will start up and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process prior to the pre-startup safety review.  



Mechanical Integrity Program  

The Station implements the maintenance program to ensure the continued integrity of the equipment in the anhydrous ammonia process. An effective maintenance program addresses equipment testing and inspection, preventative maintenance schedules, personnel training, and correction of equipment deficiencies. Preventative maintenance is performed according to equipment manufacturers' recommendations. The operations staff conduct scheduled rounds while the maintenance staff perform daily checks and visual observations as part of the routine site walkthrough.  



Hot Work Permits 

Employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing "hot work" in, on, or around the covered process. SoCalGas uses a permitting program to ensure hot work is conducted safely on or near a process involving ammonia. 



Management of Change  

SoCalGas provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of change or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions. This system allows SoCalGas staff to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data before the proposed change would either compromise system safety or need training to be completed. 



Compliance Audits 

Compliance audits are completed and documented for the covered process at least once every 3 years. Compliance audits for the anhydrous ammonia process will be performed by a team that includes at least one person knowledgeable in the anhydrous a

mmonia process and an audit leader knowledgeable in CalARP Program requirements and audit techniques. The compliance audits evaluate the prevention program elements and their implementation for compliance with the CalARP regulation.  



Incident Investigation 

Following an incident that resulted in or could have reasonably resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia, the Station staff will initiate incident investigation procedures and ensure that any resulting corrective actions are addressed and documented. The investigation will begin as soon as possible, no later than 48 hours after the incident.  The incident investigation reports will be retained for five years. 



ES.7 Planned Changes to Improve Safety  



Several studies have been conducted to improve the safety of the ammonia process at the Station including: 

?    The process hazard analyses conducted in November 2020 and August 2021 

?    The most recent seismic assessment was conducted in July 2021 

During these studies and inspections, several additional risk reduction measures were recommended to improve safety at the Station. Details of the recommendations from the process hazard analysis and the seismic assessment can be found in the prevention program document. The risk reduction measures include confirming vendor procedures and verifying pressure safety valve set pressures. The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of the ammonia system.
